summary: The Season 3 premiere is highlighted by Ullman as airport-security screener Chanel, who leads a group of boarding passengers in an impromptu dance production to a selection of Michael Jackson songs. Ullman also plays Penélope Cruz playing Salma Hayek playing artist Frida Kahlo. Other celebrity impersonations include Rachel Maddow, Arianna Huffington, Congressman Barney Frank and Christiane Amanpour.

Among Tracey Ullman's impersonations are Aaron Spelling's widow, Candy, who is looking for an assistant to handle personal-hygiene issues; Matthew McConaughey, in his change-of-pace film about a man with breast cancer; and the Octomom's mother, who is really tired of having to babysit her daughter's brood. Ullman also plays pharmacist Padma Prakash in a Bollywood salute to "Slumdog Millionaire" and a Jewish woman looking for a partner via an Internet-dating service.
Impersonations include actress Kate Winslet; a representative of an architectural commission; a vocal coach; an environmental activist; and a road-raging driver.

Ullman plays a Caribbean caregiver whose client lost her fortune in the Bernie Madoff scam; a stem-cell researcher hoping to clone Rupert Murdoch; and a flight attendant hosing down passengers to contain viruses they may be carrying into the U.S. At Graceland, she portrays a gift-shop manager all shook up over losing business to Michael Jackson's Neverland Ranch; and in San Francisco, she's an "Antiques Roadshow" expert evaluating a special piece of "Summer of Love" memorabilia.

Impersonations include Scottish singer Susan Boyle, who is engaged in secret talks to conquer America; first lady of France Carla Bruni as she arrives in Washington, D.C., to present the Obamas with gifts, including a special song for the U.S. first lady; an Idaho meth cooker whose plans go up in smoke; a woman who was kidnapped as a child and held hostage for almost 40 years by her father; and an airport-security screener on her way to be feted at a Homeland Security gala.

Ullman impersonates Simon Cowell's caustic sister Simona, who gives a harsh assessment to her lunch; overworked journalist Christiane Amanpour dealing with jet lag; and Kate Winslet discussing her penchant for performing in period-piece productions. Ullman also plays a TSA screener dressing down an exotic-animal smuggler, an overweight Southern nutritionist and an "American Idol" singing coach who promises to teach her pupil the "vocal pyrotechnics to get you to Hollywood."

In the third-season finale, Ullman portrays Caroline Kennedy, who's having an identity crisis, a CSI-type forensic scientist, and an "Antiques Roadshow" appraiser who stumbles across a priceless piece of Americana. She also appears as a once-wealthy woman who turns squatter in a Florida mansion and a trigger-happy Texas gun zealot.

The second-season opener features Ullman as former first lady Laura Bush and Beatle Paul McCartney's ex-wife Heather Mills, plus Bollywood pharmacist Padma Perkesh and airport-security screener Chanel Monticello.

Ullman portrays one of the wives of a Texas polygamist, and Renee Zellweger as the star of the Broadway polygamy musical "Seven Brides for Every Brother," as well as "Sopranos" star Tony Sirico in an audition for the play. She also appears as Arianna Huffington, former First Lady Laura Bush and fashion designer Donna Karan.

Ullman portrays Harry Potter author J.K. Rowling on her "American litigation tour" in which she sets out to protect her copyrighted material, and actress Renee Zellweger, who's starring in a biopic of the novelist. Other characterizations include Miley Cyrus's country-singing granny and Lindsay Lohan's reality-show pitching mother, Dina Lohan.
Ullman portrays newswoman Campbell Brown, a glamorous game-show hostess, a judge on "Dancing With the Stars," Catholic nun Mother Rose Panatella and the Dalai Lama's publicist.
Among Ullman's characterizations are Tom Brokaw, a soldier home on leave, a worker at a natural-food store and a soccer mom who gets a little too into the game.

Ullman portrays actors Seth Rogen and Jonah Hill, a performer in a piano bar, a dog walker, an illegal immigrant who's the proud owner of an iPod and a former TV star's daughter who has spent too much time in the sun.
Ullman portrays Jodie Foster, a doctor with a tendency to overprescribe medications, an Olympic trainer and a 50-year-old schoolteacher with a penchant for seducing students.

Tracey Ullman portrays a host of characters in day-in-the-life sketches about various U.S. residents, including Arianna Huffington, Tony "Paulie Walnuts" Sirico, Rita Cosby and David Beckham. She also plays Lindsay Lohan's mother, the wife of a death-row inmate and an "undocumented worker from Bangladesh" who works for an elderly racist. Scott Bakula costars. Peter Strauss is the narrator.

Skits include Tracey Ullman portraying environmentalist Laurie David hitting on the pilot of her "green" jet, Arianna Huffington at a blogger awards show and Renee Zellwegger promoting her latest movie. Also: Padma the pharmacist performs a Bollywood production number about erectile dysfunction.

Tracey Ullman portrays the most famous movie star in the African nation of Malawi who is in the U.S. to adopt an American child, and actress Judi Dench in an interview and clips from her latest film, a Martin Scorsese production in which she plays an Alzheimer's victim. Scott Bakula.

TSA screener Chanel confiscates tweezers because they could be "pilot killers"; "iconic curmudgeon" Andy Rooney does a pointed essay on pencils; an artificially inseminated 70-year-old from Mississippi gives birth to a child who will be "convalescent-home schooled." Ullman also impersonates Cameron Diaz and David Beckham.

Tracey Ullman impersonates Suzanne Somers selling a gynecological exerciser on a cable shopping show, and Helen Mirren discussing her latest nude film scene. Also: injury-prone soccer star David Beckham; an un-PC nun; a Russian U.N. interpreter; investigative journalist Rita Cosby.
The eighth head-to-head, single-elimination tournament continues in Las Vegas with Round of 64 matches.
Second-round coverage of the eighth annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas.

The seventh annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament gets under way in Las Vegas with first-round matches. Included: Phil Laak vs. Daniel Negreanu; David Williams vs. Emmitt Smith; and Don Cheadle vs. Tom Dwan.

The seventh annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament gets under way in Las Vegas with first-round matches. Included: Jennifer Tilly vs. Doyle Brunson; Jason Alexander vs. Liv Boeree and Greg Raymer vs. Mike Matusow.

Second-round coverage of the seventh annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Included: Jonathan Duhamel vs. Antonio Esfandiari; Emmitt Smith vs. Andrew Robi; and Phil Laak vs. Michael Mizrachi.

Round-of-16 action in the seventh annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Included: Doyle Brunson vs. Chris Moneymaker; Erik Seidel vs. Phil Gordon; and Jonathan Duhamel vs. Ayaz Mahmood.

Quarterfinal action in the seventh head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Matches are Chris Moneymaker vs. David Oppenheim; Jonathan Duhamel vs. Olivier Busquet; Erik Seidel vs. Vanessa Selbst; and Andrew Robl vs. David Benyamine.

The semifinals and the best-of-three final match in the sixth annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Semifinal matches are Chris Moneymaker vs. Jonathan Duhamel; and Andrew Robl vs. Erik Seidel. The overall champ wins $750,000.
First-round coverage of the sixth annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Matches include Phil Evey vs. Gavin Smith, and Daniel Negreanu vs. Jason Mercier.
First-round matches include Howard Lederer vs. Phil Hellmuth; defending champ Huck Seed vs. Erik Seidel; and Orel Hershiser vs. Annette Obrestad.
Second-round coverage of the sixth annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Included: Phil Ivey vs. Scotty Nguyen and Doyle Brunson vs. Don Cheadle.

Round-of-16 action in the sixth annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Included: Doyle Brunson vs. Annette Obrestad; Scotty Nguyen vs. Gabe Kaplan; and Annie Duke vs. Paul Wasicka.

Quarterfinal action in the sixth annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Matches are Scotty Nguyen vs. Jason Mercier; Doyle Brunson vs. Dennis Phillips; Jerry Yang vs. Annie Duke; and Peter Eastgate vs. Erik Seidel.

The semifinals and the best-of-three final match in the fifth annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Semifinal matches are Annie Duke vs. Dennis Phillips, and Scotty Nguyen vs. Erik Seidel. The overall champ wins $500,000.
First-round coverage of the fifth annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Matches include Daniel Negreanu vs. Chris Moneymaker; and Gabe Kaplan vs. Chris Ferguson.
Opening-round play in the fifth annual head-to-head event in Las Vegas. Matches include Johnny Chan vs. Eli Elezra; and Annie Duke vs. Brad Garrett.

Second-round coverage of the fifth annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Included: Gus Hansen vs. Huck Seed; Daniel Negreanu vs. Dario Minieri; and Jeffrey Ishbia vs. Phil Hellmuth.

Round-of-16 action in the fifth annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Included: Erick Lindgren vs. David Williams; Phil Hellmuth vs. Tom Dwan; and Scotty Nguyen vs. Daniel Negreanu.

Quarterfinal action in the fifth annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Matches include David Oppenheim vs. Huck Seed; Vanessa Rousso vs. Daniel Negreanu; and David Williams vs. Sam Farha.

The semifinals and the best-of-three final match in the fifth annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Semifinal matches are Sam Farha vs. Huck Seed; and Vanessa Rousso vs. Bertrand Grospellier.

First-round coverage of the fourth annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Matches include Chris Ferguson vs. John Juanda; Don Cheadle vs. Gus Hansen; and Patrik Antonius vs. Gabe Kaplan.

First-round coverage of the fourth annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Matches include Ted Forrest vs. Orel Hershiser; Jason Alexander vs. Huck Seed; and Shannon Elizabeth vs. Andy Bloch.

Second-round coverage of the fourth annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Included: Orel Hershiser vs. Allen Cunningham; Doyle Brunson vs. Erick Lindgren; Phil Ivey vs. Johnny Chan.

Round-of-16 action in the fourth annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Included: Orel Hershiser vs. Freddy Deeb; David Benyamine vs. Doyle Brunson; Mike Matusow vs. Chris Ferguson.

Quarterfinal action in the fourth annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Matches include Orel Hershiser vs. Andy Bloch; David Benyamine vs. Huck Seed; and Jonathan Little vs. Chris Ferguson.
The semifinals and the best-of-three final match in the fourth annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Players include Huck Seed, Chris Ferguson, Andy Bloch and Phil Ivey.
First-round coverage of the third annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Matches include Jennifer Tilly vs. Jamie Gold; and Mike Matusow vs. Daniel Negreanu.
First-round coverage of the third annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Matches include Don Cheadle vs. Phil Ivey; and Gabe Kaplan vs. Todd Brunson.
First-round coverage of the third annual head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Matches include Shannon Elizabeth vs. René Angélil; and Chris Moneymaker vs. Joe Hachem.
Second-round coverage of the single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Matches include Shannon Elizabeth vs. Jeff Madson; and Don Cheadle vs. Scott Fischman. Winners advance to the round of 16.

Third-round coverage of the single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Matches include Humberto Brenes vs. Huck Seed; and Shannon Elizabeth vs. Barry Greenstein. Winners advance to the quarterfinals.
Quarterfinal-round coverage of the single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Matches include Shannon Elizabeth vs. Humberto Brenes; and Kristy Gazes vs. Chad Brown.

The semifinals and championship match of the single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Shannon Elizabeth faces Paul Wasicka and Gavin Smith takes on Chad Brown in the semis. The final is best-of three.

First-round coverage of the second annual $1.5 million head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Players include defending champ Phil Hellmuth, Annie Duke, Scotty Nguyen, Jennifer Tilly, Mike Matusow and Howard Lederer.

First-round coverage of the second annual $1.5 million head-to-head, single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Players include actor James Woods, Lakers owner Jerry Buss, Doyle Brunson and Johnny Chan.

Second-round coverage of the $1.5 million single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Matches include Josh Arieh vs. Chris Ferguson, and Daniel Negreanu vs. T.J. Cloutier. Winners advance to the round of 16.
Third-round coverage of the $1.5 million single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Matches include Chris Ferguson vs. Chip Reese and Ted Forrest vs. Chad Brown.
Quarterfinal-round coverage of the $1.5 million single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Matches include James McManus vs. Chris Ferguson and Ted Forrest vs. Sam Farha.

The semifinals and championship match of the $1.5 million single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Chris Ferguson faces Huckleberry Seed and Sean Sheikhan challenges Ted Forrest in the semis. The final is best-of three, with the winner taking home $500,000.
First-round matches in the single-elimination tournament include Doyle Brunson vs. Billy Baxter, and Henry Orenstein vs. Chip Reese. The total purse for the Las Vegas event is $1.5 million.

First-round coverage of the $1.5 million single-elimination tournament continues from Las Vegas. Matches include Johnny Chan vs. actor James Woods and Lakers owner Jerry Buss vs. Daniel Negreanu. The championship match airs on May 22.

Second-round coverage of the $1.5 million single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Matches include Daniel Negreanu vs. Antonio Esfandiari, and Phil Hellmuth vs. Paul Phillips. Winners advance to the round of 16.
Round of 16 coverage of the $1.5 million single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. Matches include T.J. Cloutier vs. John Hennigan and Antonio Esfandiari vs. Ted Forrest.
Quarterfinal-round coverage of the $1.5 million single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas.
The semifinals and championship match of the $1.5 million single-elimination tournament in Las Vegas. The final is a best-of three competition, with the winner taking home $500,000.
Ten bakers celebrate the bountiful fruits and bright colors of the season by making fruity, tie-dye mini cheesecakes. The Season 4 premiere.
Nine bakers must create cupcake flower arrangements and use flower essences.

In the pre-heat, the eight bakers work in teams to create springtime mini pies perfect for an outdoor gathering. In the main heat, the competitors make desserts using three items from a picnic basket, but they can't make the same thing as their picnic partners.

Eggs represent spring and new beginnings better than anything else, and because eclairs use a lot of eggs, the seven bakers take on springtime eclairs in this pre-heat challenge. Then host Ali Khan asks the bakers to create edible spring goodie baskets filled with two types of baked treats—one of which must use a hard-boiled egg.
The six bakers create berry tiny desserts that pack a big punch.

The five bakers must use only agave as the sweetener in an assigned dessert—a tart, a flourless cake, an ice cream sandwich, a donut or a cupcake. For the main heat, the bakers make succulent cakes that rival the real thing.

In the pre-heat, the four bakers must pair avocado with chocolate, lime, orange or ginger in a dessert. In the main heat, the bakers "springify" a winter dessert like pumpkin pie, pecan pie, bread pudding or peppermint bark.

The remaining three bakers have to use so-called ugly ingredients to make beautiful desserts; the focus is on geodes during the pre-heat, which look like rocks on the outside, but have mineral formations inside; and the bakers are tasked with creating vibrant and colorful geode cakes using handmade rock candy.
Nine top-notch bakers in America embrace the spirit of the spring baking season by creating Easter egg desserts and bunny cakes in the Season 3 premiere.
For the eight remaining bakers, spring vacations inspire tropical desserts and destination donuts based on locations, including a poolside resort, a spring cruise, and a Vegas getaway.
The seven remaining bakers celebrate the Kentucky Derby with their takes on mint julep desserts and cookie garlands.
When the weather gets nice, it's time for some remodeling. Included: The six remaining bakers attempt to lighten up a dense, dark brownie and give a classic Napoleon a springtime twist.

The five competing bakers create fruit tarts from the heart in a kaleidoscope of colors and flavors. Next, they give vintage dessert and "mom classics" like peach cobbler, bread pudding, chocolate cream pie and pineapple upside-down cake a makeover.
The four bakers must make whoopie pie critters found in a garden. Next, the bakers must capture the drips and drops of rainfall in a cake.

The three finalists finish up with a bang in the Season 3 finale. First, it is a sweet and savory patriotic picnic followed by a salute to the red, white and blue with American flag cakes. When the flour dust settles, one lucky baker will be celebrating a $50,000 victory.

Berries play a prominent role in both challenges that kick off Season 2. To start, the classic springtime fruit is off-limits during a shortcake makeover; and later, the eight competing bakers must create a berry tasty naked cake.
Seven bakers remain for the challenge to create sweet treats using ballpark food classics, including popcorn, nachos and soft pretzels. Later, they make BBQ impostor desserts.
The bakers are given the task of making a delicious dessert dip. Later, colorful rainbows inspire their creations.
Five bakers remain. Challenges include turning farm-fresh vegetables into delectable desserts; and paying sweet homage to bacon and eggs.
A Mother's Day challenge begins with the four remaining bakers being inspired by gifts. Later, they take on chocolate.

In the Season 2 finale, the three remaining bakers start off making hospitable snacks for the welcome baskets for a destination wedding. Later, cakes inspired by Mexico, Hawaii and Italy determine who wins the $50,000 grand prize.

Eight bakers compete, preparing delicious springtime desserts for the chance to win the grand prize of $50,000 in this series, which begins with back-to-back challenges: flower-inspired cupcakes and upside-down cakes using fresh fruit.

Seven bakers remain to compete in back-to-back challenges that take sweet and tart to a whole new territory as they vie to make the best honey dessert, plus they have to create citrus treats using lemons and limes.
The bakers celebrate Mother's Day during challenges, which include transforming coffee and cream into a delectable dessert. Also: They must whip up a festive mom-worthy brunch.
Five bakers remain for a birthday bash challenge, which requires them to create desserts on a stick and an amazing cake to be paired with homemade ice cream.
In the penultimate challenge, Memorial Day desserts are prepared by the final four bakers, who are judged on their picnic pies and treats that are red, white and blue.
A dessert table and a wedding cake are produced by the three remaining bakers competing for the $50,000 grand prize in the Season 1 finale.
Season 4 begins with Belle entertaining a new business proposition, dealing with an unwelcome houseguest, handling a difficult client and wondering about committing to her best friend, Ben.
Belle suffers an identity crisis as she realizes how many roles she plays. Later, a shock is in store for Belle when she meets Ben's mother.
Belle's ability to separate work from pleasure is tested when she meets an alluring new client; Poppy's curiosity gets the better of her.
Belle tries to help Poppy come to terms with recent revelations; a cruel trick by dominatrix Charlotte leaves Belle in an awkward position.

A quarrel with Ben sends Belle off to work on her movie in New York, where she's determined to leave behind all the drama and complications of her life in London. Elsewhere, Poppy puts the moves on Ben.
Belle arrives home from New York in a fighting mood, so she unleashes the closet wrestler in a client and confronts dominatrix Charlotte.
Belle gets really involved in some vampire role-playing but the appointment doesn't end well; Ben maintains a chilly attitude toward Belle; and Harry and Poppy remain on the scene.
The series comes to a conclusion as Ben asks Belle to quit her profession.

In the third-season opener, Belle goes incognito to her book's launch party to gauge reaction to her roman à clef. Her editor, Duncan (James D'Arcy), tries to coax her into writing a follow-up novel, but she fears she doesn't have enough material for a sequel. In the glow of her success, some darkness falls upon Belle's door with the unexpected arrival of her sister Jackie (Joanna Bobin), who's left her cheating husband and seeks a place to crash.

In an effort to help Jackie better understand her profession, Belle takes her to a sex club that specializes in peoples' fetishes, and the visit proves most enlightening---to both women. Elsewhere, Bambi has a first appointment with an aristocratic young man and finds herself quite attracted to him. And while battling writer's block, Belle seeks guidance from her editor, Duncan.

Business becomes pleasure when Duncan and Belle's editor-writer relationship takes a turn after a late-night chat about her next book. Elsewhere, Belle has difficulty accepting the affair between Jackie and Ben; and Bambi begins to have feelings for a handsome, young client, despite warnings from Belle about getting involved with her "dates."

Belle offers relationship advice to Ben as his romance with Jackie turns rocky, and Bambi, who is dating her client Byron. But when it comes to her own love life, Belle breaks all the rules she set for her friends.

Belle contemplates the possibility of a serious relationship with Duncan, but she has second thoughts when he refuses to acknowledge that they have been intimate. Meanwhile, Bambi's romance with Byron takes a major turn.
The initial meeting between Ben and Duncan is a bit rocky, leaving Belle with a serious decision to make.

To gain a more accurate understanding of the client-escort relationship, Belle hires a man's services for the evening, but begins to feel guilty about cheating on Duncan. The feeling doesn't last long, however, when she learns that her boyfriend spent some quality time with Bambi earlier that night.

Season 3 wraps up with a bombshell about Duncan and Bambi's nocturnal rendezvous being dropped at her wedding, leaving Belle devastated, but providing her with plenty of dirt for the final chapter of her book. Meanwhile, lovelorn Ben drops a bombshell of his own.

While waiting at a hotel bar, Belle mistakes a handsome man for her client and they hit it off, but when the real customer shows up, he turns out to be quite a handful. Later, an inexperienced new escort gets the lay of the land from Belle, who's somewhat distracted with thoughts of the hunk she encountered earlier at the bar.

Belle considers breast-enhancement surgery; concern for Bambi and her prostitution prospects leads Belle to arrange an introduction to Stephanie and the opportunity to join forces with her, but the novice hooker elects to stay on her own. Belle goes against her professional rules of conduct and accepts a date with Alex.
After a session with one of her regular clients, Belle is confronted by the man's angry wife, which has her second-guessing her decision to enter into a real relationship with Alex (Callum Blue).

When the escort business hits a lull, Belle agrees to a professional three-way with Bambi and a nightclub owner, but her heart isn't in it because she's preoccupied with thoughts of Alex, with whom she is falling in love.
On the day that Belle decides to tell Alex about her "profession," he catches her in the act with a client, so Alex confronts Ben about why he never told him about her real line of work.

Her break-up with Alex leaves Belle free to concentrate solely on the job and she accepts Bambi's offer to work a sex party at a country manor, where she violates one of her cardinal rules and has a few drinks, loses control and lands herself and Bambi in trouble with the client.

Belle has regrets about spending the night with Ben and decides to ask Alex for a second chance, and to prove she's serious, chucks her call-girl accoutrements and takes a temp job. Ben, reveling in his evening tryst with Belle, realizes he still has feelings for her and leaves Vanessa.

In the second-season finale, Belle and Alex make a go at a relationship, but Stephanie's offer of one final job for Belle, with a mystery date who asked specifically for her, is too much of a temptation for Belle to resist.

A high-priced London escort entertains a middle-aged client who enjoys role-playing and has a penchant for being down on the farm, plus a younger lad who isn't satisfied with the kind of date who turns up at his hotel the first time around.
Belle dresses to impress when a new client takes her to London's most prestigious sex party.
Belle's time-management skills are tested when a client books her for an entire evening.
Ben tells Belle he's engaged to Vanessa.
Ben shops for a wedding suit with Belle while still reeling from her recent revelation.
Belle meets a scary client after a bad review on the Internet hurts business and forces her to take a midnight booking from what had appeared to be an ordinary guy.
Ben shocks Belle when he says he wants to join her for a gig with a couple.
Belle meets a high-class client, an American film producer who assures her she has what it takes to become a courtesan.
Penelope worries about changes she sees in Alex, who gets in trouble at school. Elena wonders if others are misidentifying her based on her appearance.
When juggling family, work and college proves too much for Penelope, Schneider offers her a way to sharpen her focus and improve her test grades.
Lydia gives Elena advice on approaching her crush. After running into a hunky Army buddy who's also single again, Penelope rethinks her dating rules.
Elena is horrified to learn that her grandmother doesn't vote. Penelope teaches her son all her tricks on how to save money at the movie theater.
Penelope's furtive date at home with Max is interrupted when a neighborhood lockdown brings the rest of the family back early.
To teach Alex the value of a dollar, Penelope forces him to take a summer job at her workplace. Meanwhile, Elena finds a way to get paid for her hobby.
Lydia learns Dr. Berkowitz is going to the opera without her. When Schneider asks if she and Max are exclusive, Penelope realizes it's time for a talk.
Penelope recalls Elena's birth in 2001, and how an unexpected turn of events drastically changed the life plans she and her husband had made.
Feeling like she's finally got her life together, Penelope unwisely stops taking her antidepressants so she doesn't have to tell Max she's on them.
As Schneider's trainee, Elena learns there's more to being a building super than fixing things. Penelope battles Lydia over the space in their garage.

Penelope has her work cut out for her trying to convince her feminist daughter Elena to embrace her Cuban roots with a traditional quinceañera for her 15th birthday in the series premiere of this remake of Norman Lear's classic 1975 sitcom.
When Penelope and Elena complain about not being taken seriously as women at work and school, Lydia offers advice from an older generation.
When Lydia disappears after a heated argument with her daughter about religion, the smooth running of the household falls apart in her absence.
Penelope suddenly finds herself back in the dating game after Schneider shows her how to use an online app for meeting people.
Lydia grows suspicious of Elena and Carmen's intense relationship. Penelope later discovers that the inseparable friends are keeping a big secret.
When Penelope's faithful car finally breaks down for good and she's forced to trade it in, she meets a kindred spirit in the unlikeliest of places.
While navigating her way through an endless maze of red tape with Veterans Affairs to make a medical appointment, Penelope reaches her breaking point.
Penelope tells her family she has a date and Lydia says she's going to church, but each secretly goes elsewhere. Meanwhile, Elena tests an attraction.
Elena gets a congratulatory letter that leaves a bitter taste in her mouth. For a school project, Alex interviews Lydia, who reveals a family secret.
When Penelope finds porn on Alex's laptop, she struggles to talk to him about sex, but their reluctant conversation leads to a surprising discovery.
